stories.text:
Setting up Route 53 domains with Heroku apps had confused me in the past and caused unnecessary time consumption. So I made a set of instructions that shouldn't take more than 30 minutes to complete. Hope it saves you some time as well.

https://steve-condylios.medium.com/how-to-set-up-an-aws-route-53-custom-domain-for-your-heroku-app-266b60297f3b
stories.title: How to set up an AWS Route 53 custom domain for your Heroku app

stories.text:
Working in academy taught me one huge concept about editorial world. Some publishing houses that work exclusively for profit tend to focus more on the quantity than on the quality.

For some months by browsing HN, I've been amazed at how many open books written by normal people (self-published resources) that need to be discovered. So I was wondering: is there anywhere a list of "open" books? Let's give some authors some notoriety, if you found one, please comment below!

A books/resource to be defined as "open source" should have the following features:

- have a good quality content â€“ it is a little bit hard to achieve, especially when you do not have money to hire editors;

- be free as PDF/HTML, but the author can still have donations, or can be paid for hardcopies;

- anyone can contribute to writing or editing! "source code"/content of the book is hosted in a Git instance;
stories.title: Ask HN: Which are the best open source books?
